div.p: 1. IV. Saturday.

Shortened my Morning walk, to return in time to see the Sun rise from the Eastern window in the upper Story of the house— Dr Everett called and visited me— Mr Johnson and Mrs Frye were here. After dinner, Mrs Tudor who is my next door neighbour sent, a request to me to come to her, which I did, and found her and her daughter Mrs Stewart in great distress— She gave me to read, a Letter from Mr Wright Consul of the United States at Rio de Janeiro to Mr Van Buren, Secretary of State, dated 13. March, announcing the decease on the 9th of that Month of William Tudor, Charge d’Affaires at the Court of Brazil: Mrs Tudor’s oldest Son. The old Lady was composed, and conversed with full self possession. Mrs Stewart was bewailing bitterly their misfortune, and could not be comforted— Her daughter, a girl of about fourteen, was shewing her every possible filial attention— I sat with them about half an hour, and said what I could to sooth them— Their loss is irreparable; and the Country has lost an upright, able, and faithful public servant— Mrs Stewart asked me to write a biographical notice of him for publication, of which I promised to consider— He was the Son of William Tudor, one of my father’s pupils and throughout life, a kind and affectionate friend— He was born at Boston in 1777—graduated at Cambridge in 1796. Sometime a member of the Legislature of Massachusetts—appointed by Mr Monroe 9. Decr. 1823. Consul for Lima, and the Ports of Peru—and by me in 1827. Charge d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro— He was one of the very few persons, whom upon my own favourable opinion, I brought into the public Service, in distinguished Office, and who by his Services more than answered my expectations— He negotiated an excellent Treaty of Commerce with Brazil; and obtained indemnity for numerous injuries committed by Brazilian Officers during their War with Buenos Ayres, which had been much aggravated by the rashness and intemperance of Condy Raguet, another of my own appointments; but one whose folly, ruined himself and disgraced as far as he could disgrace me; and who of course returns my unmerited kindness by base ingratitude. He brought this Country and Brazil to the very verge of War—raved and stormed with the Brazilian Government, till he had left himself nothing else to do; and then without authority demanded his Passports and came home. Tudor was a perfect contrast with him in character. His temper was conciliatory, his manners pleasing—his deportment respectful; he healed the breaches between the two governments, and succeeded completely in his Mission— The present Administration did not remove him, and I had hoped he would yet have rendered more important Services to his Country— It has been otherwise disposed—my duty is acquiescence, and perhaps to perform a last act of friendship to this worthy man; and of kindness to his aged and afflicted mother— I took and Evening ride with John— The child quite unwell—and disqualifying Summer here.
2. IV:45. Sunday.

Heard a Stranger at Mr Campbell’s Church from Hebrews. 7.1. “For this Melchisedec, king of Salem, priest of the most High God, who met Abraham, returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him; 2 To whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of all; first being by interpretation King of righteousness, and after that also King of Salem, which is, King of Peace; 3. Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life; but made like unto the Son of God; abideth a priest continually”— The preacher gave some account of the diversities of opinion which have prevailed—first concerning the author of this Epistle. Barnabas Luke, or Paul—but said a Dissertation recently published by a Countryman of our own
had proved nearly beyond dispute that Paul was the author; and so I had supposed it had been always considered by all, excepting for purposes of controversy—secondly to whom the Epistle was written— This I had not heard questioned before. It is extraordinary that there is nothing on the face of the Letter expressly declaring either who was the writer, or to whom it was written—and in this respect it differs from all the other Epistles of the New Testament— Some reasons were suggested why the apostle should have chosen to conceal himself, because the design of the Letter was to make converts from the Hebrew faith, and the knowledge of the author might have predisposed the Jews against him. The principal subject of the Discourse however was the character of Melchisedec—first mentioned in the 14th. chapter of Genesis— Then in the 110th Psalm and lastly in the 6th. and 7th. Chapter of this Epistle to the Hebrews— Melchizedek, was king of Salem—he was the priest of the most high God—he blessed Abraham who gave him Tythes— The Levitical Law, declared the children of Israel to be Gods chosen people: and the priesthood was confined to the family of Levi— The 110th. Psalm is prophetical, and declares the Messiah, a Priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek— Paul combines the passage in Genesis with that in the Psalms, and argues with great acuteness, that the Priesthood of Aaron must give way, and fell before that of Melchizedek—but there is more in the argument of Paul— He states that Melchizedek was king of Righteousness and king of Peace— That he was made like unto the Son of God—immortal—and a high-priest for ever— The whole argument of Paul, represents him as of a nature higher in the scale of creation than mortal man—yet he calls him a man— Our preacher told us that he had been supposed absurdly by some to be the holy Ghost, and by one sect of the Melchizedekians, to be superior to Christ himself— He concluded with the doctrine of the atonement Mrs Adams heard Mr Tyng at St. John’s— Coll. Dwight paid us a visit after the morning Service— The Sunday School Union, were in the afternoon at St. John’s and in the Evening at Dr. Laurie’s— John dined at Mr Frye’s— At dusk I walked and called at General Macomb’s, where I saw Mrs Roberdeau and Mary who had called yesterday to visit our Ladies with General Macomb’s daughter. General Macomb was now not at home, and Mrs Macomb was unwell— Evening sultry, and distressing—
3: V. Monday.

Morning walk with rain— The approach of Summer affects exceedingly my power of writing— I called again upon Mrs Tudor, and Mrs Stewart, with a Memorandum of questions concerning the principal events in the life of William Tudor; but found neither of them could tell even his age at the time of his death— Mrs Stewart said he entered the University at the age of 13. and Mrs Tudor afterwards sent me, my minutes; with Boston in 1778 in answer to the question of the Time and place of his birth, but with scarcely any other information respecting the objects of my enquiries— In the evening I wrote part of a page for an obituary notice, but found myself obliged to generalize every thing; and soon to stop in utter dissatisfaction with what I had written— To get through the Evening I finished reading Shakespear’s Play of Julius Caesar; which now struck me according to the criticism of Dr Johnson as cold and deficient in interest. The beauties
of the Play consist in particular passages; and in the pictures of the Passions— One of the Commentators justly observes that the Title should have been not Julius Caesar—but Marcus Brutus— The Moral is to be traced from two passages—first the description by Brutus—Act 2. Scene 1. of the State of his own mind— Since Cassius first did whet him against Caesar.— The second is the character of Brutus given by Antony in the last Scene: beginning This was the noblest Roman of them all— Brutus, instigated by another headed a conspiracy which murdered Caesar— The purpose of the Poet is to shew how such a man could be prompted to such an act—and how it operated afterwards upon his mind and fortunes. Orestes for the murder of his mother was tortured by the Furies— Brutus was haunted by a Phantom; his Evil Genius— Shakespear has drawn him, consistent in character throughout— A fearful picture it is— I remark further that although the comment upon the State of mind, which accompanies deep conspiracies is general yet the observation of it is suitable only to Brutus— He reflects upon what is passing in his own bosom; and he tells that which is applicable though not equally to all— Suppose this speech to be made by Cassius and it would be entirely out of character— Suppose it made even by Brutus to Cassius, as an objection to the conspiracy, and it would be out of place— Brutus communes with his own heart, and describes its convulsions as matter of philosophical speculation— There is in this Edition, a Letter from Warburton to Concanen, upon this passage of Shakespear, compared with one, in Addison’s Cato—like all Warburton’s criticisms acute, ingenious and fanciful— There is a singular objection of Brutus to making the conspiracy known to Cicero—that he would never follow any thing that other men begin— Plutarch’s conjecture is that they distrusted his courage or his age.
4. V. Tuesday.

Mr Sill a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania introduced Mr Sheffield of Springfield Massachusetts. Mr Sparks afterwards called and enquired again concerning Mr Graham of Frederick— Sparks said he had been spending a week at Mr Madison’s, who spoke to him much of the proceedings and published Journal of the Convention of 1787. He said he knew not what to make of the plan of Constitution in that volume purporting to have been presented by Charles Pinckney of South-Carolina. He said there was a paper presented by that person to the Convention, but it was nothing like the paper now in the book— It was referred to the Committee who drafted the plan of the Constitution, and was never afterwards in any manner referred to, or noticed— In the book, it has the appearance as if it was the original draught of the Constitution itself, and as if that which was finally adopted was Pinckney’s plan with a very few slight alterations— I told Mr Sparks that Rufus King had spoken to me of C. Pinckney’s paper, precisely in the same manner, as he says Mr Madison now does— That it was a paper to which no sort of attention was paid by the Convention, except that of referring it to the Committee, but when I compiled the Journal of the Convention Charles Pinckney himself sent me the plan now in the Book, as the paper which he had presented to the Convention, and with it he wrote me a Letter, which obviously held the pretension, that the whole plan of Constitution was his, and that the Convention had done nothing more than to deteriorate his work, by altering some of his favourite provisions.
Sparks said Mr Madison added that the plan now in the book contained several things, which could not possibly have been in Pinckney’s paper, but which rose out of the debates upon the plan of Constitution reported by the Committee. He conjectured that Mr Pinckney’s Memory had failed him, and that instead of a copy of the paper which he did present, he had found a copy of the plan reported by the Committee, with interlined amendments perhaps proposed by him; and at a distance of more than thirty years had imagined it was his own plan— Charles Pinckney was of loose morals and as R. King said to me of crapulous life. And I never knew a man of that character who had any scrupulous regard to truth— Virtue may recover from the sensualities of youthful frailty, but an old lecher is a universal profligate, who will lie and steal, and cheat, for any sordid and selfish purpose— We rode this Evening round by the race-ground, and by Greenleaf’s point.
5. IV. Wednesday— Sun rose 5.3.

I found myself again this morning with a severe cold in my head a complaint constantly returning upon me; and the cause of which I can neither avoid nor trace— The weather was sultry and I shortened my morning walk to return and see the sunrise— I called upon Mrs Tudor and Mrs Stewart, the latter of whom was impatient for the publication of the obituary notice of her brother that I had promised. I therefore finished it and took it in, desiring Mrs Stewart to mark any thing which they might prefer to have altered or omitted— I met Mr Sparks at their door, and asked him to dine with us, which he did. Conversation upon modern Metaphysics which I took for disguised Atheism; and political Economy, which I pronounced political swindling— The present objects of the British Political Economists is National Bankruptcy— Rode with my Son John. This is the week of the Spring Races, and the roads about there were thronged with People— I had an Evening visit from Mr James Hillhouse formerly a Senator from Connecticut, and one of my associates in that body, during the whole time that I was one of its members. He has been here the greater part of this Session of Congress, soliciting a subscription for completing the Farmington Canal— He has also republished the Speech that he made to the Senate on the 12th of April 1808. with the Amendments to the Constitution which he then proposed; and has now added a new preface, with a new set of Amendments partly differing from those of the former period— He gave me one of the pamphlets containing his present publication. We were quite social— Mrs Stewart sent back my sketch of an obituary notice of her brother, approving it generally, but requesting several alterations and some additions.— After a very sultry day, there was a distant thundercloud in the Northwest, which followed down the course of the River; a corner of it only passing over us with a moderate Shower— I am reading every morning part of the Orations against Verres—They are divided into two Actions— The first consisting of one Oration, and the second of five— The first only was delivered, and contained a charge that Verres had taken and carried away a certain large sum of money from the Sicilians— This charge, Cicero offers to prove by witnesses and the great argument of his side is to prove that the only reliance of Verres for his defence is to get the
trial to be postponed till the next year, when Hortensius would be Consul; and the Praetors friendly to Verres; who would appoint judges accessible to his corrupt practices— But after this first Oration and the hearing of the witnesses, Verres attempted no defence; but gave up his Cause and went into exile— The five Orations of the second Action were never delivered— But they are among the most valuable monuments of antiquity; not only as models of eloquence, but as containing an authentic History of the Roman Government over their tributary Provinces.
6. V. Thursday—

The cold in my head has fallen upon my lungs, and aggravated the internal inflammation, with which I am afflicted so that I can scarcely hold a pen— This writing is the best of witnesses— Mrs Tudor sent this morning a request to see me— She wanted me to make alterations and additions to the biographical notice of her Son, some of which I could not make— She was unwilling that his appointment of Consul should be stated, unless with the Addition of General—which he was not— She disliked the title of Political Agent, an informal Office in which he served two or three years, and had one or two other objections of similar character. Tudor had accepted the appointment of Consul with great reluctance, and after having once refused it— He thought it beneath him, as it was; and there is much of this personal and family pride among us, though it is one of those feelings which we seldom acknowledge, though influenced by them— Mrs Tudor said a Brazilian Gentleman had told her that when her Son arrived at Rio de Janeiro the Affairs of the United States there, were in very bad condition; and that he had entirely changed the aspect of them— I told her I knew this very well, and had alluded to it in the obituary notice, as distinctly as I could without leading to a controversy which would be unpleasant to her— Condy Raguet Tudor’s predecessor was a man, who by my special kindness had been raised from wretchedness and bankruptcy to the honours and emoluments of a Charge d’Affaires— He was a mere fire-brand, and brought the two Countries to the brink of War—dismissed himself from Office by demanding his Passports and coming home without Orders or authority, and now because I left him to enjoy the privacy into which he had thrown himself, ingratiates himself with the Rulers of the hour by lampooning his benefactor. Tudor’s character was a perfect contrast to that of Raguet and he did by his discreet and conciliatory conduct restore the harmony which Raguet had ruined. It is proper that this should be duly recorded, but not in an obituary notice for a Newspaper. Mrs Tudor immediately acquiesced in the observation— Mr Whittlesey of the House of Representatives, introduced Mr Beebe, a friend of his from that State—a Young man by the name of James, requested an interview to make a communication to me, for which express purpose he had come all the way from Philadelphia— It was to ask me to lend him money to pursue his medical Studies. Mr and Mrs Frye dined with us— Their son Thomas came in after dinner— I rode towards Evening with my son John to the Mills— He now disposes of about 450 bushels of corn-meal a week, at the market or to customers in Washington and Georgetown— He began this business last Spring by Sales of about 150 bushels a week; and these effected with difficulty. He began with sending into the Market and Grocer’s shops daily one horse and cart—then occasionally and afterwards constantly twice a day— Then found a second horse necessary, and has for the last six weeks had a second cart with one horse constantly employed— His present Stock of Corn was purchased at 33 cents a bushel, and the meal is sold at an average of 48 cents— It is at present by far the most profitable business to which the Mills can be turned; and much the safest.
7. IV:15. Friday. Sun-rose 5.1.

A feverish Night.—this Morning a hoarse throat and sore breast; I took a Sedlitz powder and walked immediately after Sun-rise. Mr Bartley member of the House of Representatives from Ohio introduced Mr and Mrs L’hommedieu from Cincinnati and a Mr Scott of Pennsylvania— An hour’s ride with John after dinner. On our return we found Miss Mease, just from Philadelphia who spent the Evening with us— Mr Swann called with Mrs George Hay, who comes from her father’s at Oak-hill and purposes going to Baltimore where her daughter Mrs Lloyd Rogers is expected to be confined— Her husband judge Hay is here very ill. She said he wished me to call and see him, and I promised I would— The five Orations of the second action of Cicero against Verres, somewhat resemble five Articles of Impeachment. But each of them embraces a multitude of criminal Acts— The first is styled de Praetum Urbana. That is—of his misconduct while exercising the Office of Praetor at Rome— But it includes charges of oppressive and tyrannical acts, for a period of fourteen years; first as Quaester at Rome, then as Proquaestor, in the Provinces of Cilicia, Achaia, and Asia—and finally as Praetor, at Rome— He accuses him of treachery to his superior Officers Cneius Carbo and Cneius Dolabella—of many shameless Robberies of Statues and other works of Art; and of a complicated transaction of infamy; provoking a man named Philodamus and his Son at Lampsacus, to raise and head a popular insurrection, in defence of the chastity of the daughter of Philodamus; and then by a public prosecution the conviction and execution of the father and Son— There is much about an instrument of his infamous passions, named Rubrius, and a mistress named Chelidon, through whom his Edicts as Praetor were purchased. The closing part of this Oration is lost— The next is upon his exercise of the civil Jurisdiction as Praetor in Sicily— The third upon his malversations in plundering the farmers and the Cities of Sicily, of their grain—and is entitled de frumento. The fourth, is upon his robberies of Statues and works of Art—and the fifth upon his cruel executions— These are styled de Signis and de Suppliciis.— They compose together a large Volume, and he seems to have published them as a sort of compendium of all the Official crimes that could be committed by a Roman Magistrate.
8. Saturday.— Sun rose 5.

Still suffering an obstinate Catarrhal cough, the returns of which have been incessant through the Winter— Mr and Mrs Frye came this morning, and with Mrs Adams we rode to the Columbian Mills; the largest of which was at work, making flour. The small one or Corn Mill had met some accident this morning, and was not working. John was there and little Thomas J. Frye was with us— Miss Mease dined with us. I called in the Evening and saw judge Hay, who is confined to his bed, and was suffering severe pain, with what he said was called Neuralgia, a new name for a disease, occasioned by a strain in a violent effort about six weeks to save himself from breaking through a decayed plank in passing a bridge— He was too ill for holding a connected conversation, but expressed himself in terms of severest
reprobation concerning the present course of affairs— He censured especially a late order of the President dismissing from the Navy, two Lieutenants and two Midshipmen, for having been concerned recently in a duel, in which one of them, Midshipman Charles G. Hunter, killed William Miller junr. a young lawyer of Philadelphia— This duel has occasioned great excitement within the last two Months—and great diversities of opinion with regard to this arbitrary act of the President—an act the more obnoxious to comment, because it is a notorious fact that the same hand which issued this order, killed in a duel, a rival Jockey at a horse-race, for a supposed insinuation of foul play in the race— The duel, and the proceedings of the President consequent upon it, have given rise to several Newspaper and Pamphlet Publications, among which one called an Investigation of the late Philadelphia Duel is under a legal prosecution. It purports to be published by Jonathan Elliot in this City; and this Morning, returning from my walk I met him in the Pennsylvania Avenue, and purchased one of them— This pamphlet Miss Mease says was written by an Englishman named Newton— It represents a man named Drake as the blamable cause of the duel— On my return from Mr Hay’s I found Mr Bailey who spent an hour of the Evening with me.
9. V. Sunday.

Finished reading the old Testament, begun this time last year— 3 chapters every morning. The prophets are hard to be understood; and if you judge from the voluminous commentaries upon them, their difficulties are rather increased than diminished by study. At the Unitarian Church I heard Mr Hedge—this Morning from John 8.32. “And ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free.”— I was not much pleased with this Sermon. Mr Hedge and Mr Upham joined in the administration of the communion. I called to see judge Hay; whom I found suffering severe pain, though somewhat less violent than last Evening— Mr Hedge’s Evening discourse was from Jonah 4.6. [“]And the Lord prepared a gourd and made it to come up over Jonah, that it might be a shadow over his head to deliver him from his grief. So Jonah was exceeding glad of the gourd. 7. But God prepared a worm when the morning arose the next day, and it smote the gourd that it withered.”— Mr Hedge began with a series of ingenious observations, upon the extensive and even universal application of many incidents apparently trivial and insignificant in themselves with which the Scriptures abound—of which he gave the incident related in his text as a memorable example— An alternate succession of good and evil, by the direction of Providence, and operating upon human life, was then drawn as the moral inference from the text— Mr Hedge did not enter into any particular consideration of the Book of Jonah, which differs materially from all the other prophetical books— It is in truth the History of a prophecy not fulfilled— Jonah lived 840 years before Christ— In the 14th. Chapter of the second book of Kings v. 25. A prophesy of Jonah concerning the kingdom of Israel, is said to have been fulfilled by Jeroboam the second; but that prophecy is not in the book of Jonah— The Book has no apparent reference to either of the kingdoms of Israel or of Judah— Jonah was commanded by the word of the Lord to prophecy the destruction of Nineveh— He attempted to evade this command, in consequence of which the tempest arose; he was cast into the Sea; swallowed by the great fish; cast ashore by him; ordered a second time to prophecy against Nineveh, which he did— But Nineveh repented— Nineveh
Nineveh was spared, and Jonah’s prophecy was not fulfilled— Upon this Jonah was exceedingly distressed for his own character and expostulated with the Lord; insisting that he did well to be angry, and to pray for his own death— He then retires to his booth on the East side of the City—where the Lord prepares the gourd to shade him, and the worm to smite the gourd—finally the heat of the Sun which overpowers the prophet; and he again prays for death— The whole closes with a pointed sentence of reproof upon the prophet for pitying the Gourd, and yet being angry because the Lord had not destroyed the great City of Nineveh— The whole Book appears to be an Allegory or a Parable, and in its moral strongly resembles the book of Job—
10. V. Monday.

My disease abated some portion of its severity upon my lungs and reappears in the form of a lumbago— There is little probability that I shall ever be relieved from it entirely. The day was uninterrupted— After dinner I rode with John to the Mill— Mrs Adams and Mary passed the Evening with T. B. Johnson— After reading again through the Old Testament, there ought to remain more of its contents upon my Memory than there does. I have endeavoured to fix more of my attention upon the prophets at this reading than heretofore— But a very small part of them is intelligible. I have endeavoured to ascertain the precise character and condition of the Hebrew Prophets— In Genesis 20.7. Abraham is said to be a prophet, but afterwards they were for sometime called Seers— They sometimes Saw Visions— Sometimes heard Voices and sometimes dreamt dreams— They were persons who received direct supernatural communications from God which they were commanded to make known to the kings and People— Most of the Patriarchs were Prophets— So was Moses. So were most of the Judges— David and Solomon among the kings; and there was a constant succession of them during the Monarchies of Israel and of Judah— Many Psalms of David are considered as prophetic, but in the present Canon of the Scriptures, there are only sixteen Books of Prophets; four Great and twelve Minor Prophets— The Great Prophets are Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and Daniel, the last of whom so styled not for the length but for the importance of his work. The time during which the prophecies were written was about 500 years from Jonah 840 years before Christ to Malachi 397. They were written as predictions of destruction to the two kingdoms, and to all their neighbours and conquerors. Most of them also predicted the Messiah, and the kingdom of Christ upon Earth— They were admitted as Books of divine Inspiration by Christ and his Apostles, and there is scarcely one of them, from whom there are not quotations, in the Gospels and Epistles of the New Testament— The manner in which they were commissioned to deliver their Messages from Heaven was astonishing—usually by typical representations, and acts sometimes very questionable in themselves— A collection of these types would be interesting. It is also remarkable that excepting the case of Jonah it does not appear that the denuntiations of Gods wrath in all these prophets ever produced any effect to draw the people to Repentance, or to obtain for them a mitigation of the sentence to which they were doomed— The purpose of the predictions of the prophets seems to have been to prepare mankind for the reception of Christianity.
11. V. Tuesday.

My indisposition continues, and becomes more painful; but has not hitherto interfered with my occupations— I called this forenoon and visited judge Hay, and found him suffering less than when I had seen him last before. Mr Rush was with him. And a young man named Payne came in while I was there— I rode with John this afternoon to the Mill, and in the Evening wrote to Alexander H. Everett, and part of a Letter to my Son Charles— I am reading the fourth Oration of the second Action against Verres— A continued series of vituperation against one person through a large volume, must degenerate into dulness—invective should be short—when a man has once been devoted in your mind to utter execration, you cannot do more than turn him over to the infernal Gods. After the first Oration Verres gave up his Cause and went into banishment— Five long Orations of perpetual invective upon a man already self-condemned, would seem to be too much— The imcomparable address of the Orator is felt in the interest, which he never suffers to flag, and of which no reader can even now be conscious— The multitude of frauds, of cruelties, and of robberies detailed in these Orations is scarcely credible, but the names of all the parties are given, and every narration is prepared as for dramatic effect— To collect the Evidence Cicero had himself gone and spent several Weeks in the Island of Sicily, and frequently alludes to the persons with whom he conversed and to the discoveries he made there— In one instance the public accounts of a City, which contained proofs of unlawful payments to Verres, had by collusion with him been destroyed— But Cicero obtained a copy of part of them, which had been taken by one of the magistrates for his own use; and Cicero exults much of the production of it. In another case the accounts had been falsified by erasures, and alterations which Cicero describes with minuteness and much humour— There were charges to a very large amount against Verres, which had been altered to the fictitious name of Verrutius, there being no such person in existence— Cicero frequently puns upon the name of the accused Praetor, by compounding several verbs from his name, which signifies a boar. He gives an occasional description of his person and looks, and graphic portraits of some of his agents and creatures.
12. V. Wednesday.

The occasional pains which indicate an inflammation of the kidneys were this day extremely severe, yet I took my usual early walk— Met Mr James Hillhouse of Connecticut who turned and walked with me— Three or four days ago, he stopped me and asked me, if I had any objection to giving him my views upon project of Amendments to the Constitution. I did not give him a positive answer. When Mr Hillhouse on the 12th of April 1808 offered his proposal of Amendments, and read his dissertation, I did believe that he had another motive than that which appeared on the surface—namely the desire of drawing my father, or me into controversy with him— I saw clearly the advantages that he might expect to derive from that; but absurd as his proposed amendments were, there was not the slightest danger in them— And I had no inclination to fight Shadows or Windmills— When my father read Hillhouse’s book, he spoke of it to me, and intimated to me a design to expose some of its absurdities— I told him I believed that to be precisely Hillhouse’s object; and my father gave up all idea of answering him. Twenty-two
years have since passed away, and after some feeble efforts of the cabal with which Hillhouse was connected to puff his project into notice it sunk into oblivion— He never called up his Amendments in the Senate— He continued as a Senator among the most violent of the federalists, but retired from Congress in 1810. and in 1814 and 15 was a member of the Hartford Convention— The change of Politics in Connecticut took place in 1816. and Hillhouse has since that time been retired from political life—but always maintaining a respectable character— He comes here now as Agent for a Canal Company to obtain a subscription by Congress— He understands his interest too well to indispose the majorities in both houses of Congress, and the members of the present Administration by dabbling in Politics disagreeable to them— About a year since Mr Hillhouse was one of judge Gould’s certificate men, to discredit a Statement made by me which he Hillhouse well knew was true— He came here nearly three Months since; passed by me at least ten times in the Streets without the slightest notice of me, and last week first called to see me. I received him with good humour and cordiality—upon which he took from his pocket and gave me a copy of his new pamphlet, addressed to me in manuscript with his name— Since then we have met several times in my morning walk, and at last he asked me to give him my views upon his work, which he says he considers extremely important— Crafty people are apt to overreach themselves— A serious discussion of his amendments would be ridiculous; but as my antagonist, he would know how and to whom to pay his court, and might get a vote of subscription for the Farmington Canal— I had a visit this Morning from Mr Sprague—Senator from Maine— He came to ask from me for Moses Shaw a document relating to the Life of Samuel Tucker, which he is writing— I told him I had received last Fall a Letter from Mr Shaw, making the same request. It was but a few days before I left Quincy, and not having the time to examine my father’s papers I postponed answering the Letter— But I expected very shortly to return to Quincy; and would then immediately examine the papers, and answer Mr Shaw’s Letter— I took with difficulty this Evening a warm bath.
13. V.45. Thursday.

I was unable this morning to put on my own Clothes, but was indebted for it to the assistance of my wife— I can moralize upon this event as well as younger and more disinterested philosophers— It is one admonition more to set my house in order— May they not all be lost. Mr Poinsett our late Minister to Mexico, called to visit me. He has been at Philadelphia and Baltimore where they have given him public dinners; where Speeches were made and toasts given— He told me he was going immediately home to South-Carolina; even at this Season of the year, to see if he could by good advice calm the excitement which he does not share— He spoke of a toast recently given by the Governor of the State— The right to fight—and said it was unfortunate that the most violent man they had was to be their next Governor—James Hamilton. South-Carolina has been potioned and philtered and back scourged like an old lecher into a frenzy of excitement, and has now a prospect of coming into physical collision with the Government of the Union— As the Government is now administered, there is every prospect that her bullies will succeed to the sacrifice of the interest of all the rest of the Union; as the bullies of Georgia have succeeded in the project of extirpating the Indians, by the sacrifice of the public faith of the Union and of all our Treaties with them— Coll. Abert brought
back my two foot Carpenter’s Rule, which I had requested him to have measured upon the Scale of Troughton’s beam-compass at the War-Department— But the Beam-compass is packed up in its box, and Coll. Abert says the Rule is so coarsely made and warped that it could not be accurately measured. He lent me however an Ivory foot Rule, made, he said, in New-York upon a measure taken from the Tower-yard, and very correct. Mrs Frye and Mary Roberdeau dined with us, and Mr Frye called in the Evening— I took a short walk before dinner, and a ride with John towards dusk— There was a moderate Thunder shower. The day was passed not in absolute idleness; but in reading occasionally interrupted by sharp pangs, and by writing without satisfaction— I read an Article in the American Quarterly Review of September last, upon Shakespear, and some pages of Beloe’s Herodotus.
14. IV:45. Friday.— Sun rose 4.54.

The occasional severe pains of the last two days subsided, leaving some soreness, and incapacity of bodily labour— I renewed, but abridged my Morning walk, and rode with my Son John to the Mills after dinner. I found them at work, grinding wheat at the large Mill and Indian Corn at the small one. The demand for Corn meal, and for what they call Rye-chop continues, and the prospect of profitable business for the year remains fair— The experience of the last years, forbids sanguine hope; but my anxieties for the future condition of my family have no other reliance upon Earth— Mr Jefferson died at 84. amidst the most abject supplications for eleemosinary contributions for bread to his children— Mr Monroe’s groans of famishing distress are incessant, and ring throughout this continent— My father screened the poverty of his last years; by a severity of domestic frugality, which neither Jefferson, nor Monroe, nor I had energy of mind to practice— My experience of the last 15 Months leaves me nothing to expect but a rapid consumption of what property I have, to defray the cost of my own sustenance, and that of my children— If the industrious and prudent employment of these Wills, will give me no relief, the close of my animal life, will to all appearance be as needy, and as comfortless as that of Mr Jefferson—yet will I not despair— Mr Fendall called and asked me again for that manuscript dissertation upon parties which I had written and which yet remains unfinished. I told him I would look for it. There is doubt in my mind whether Fendall will ever write the History of the late Administration which was advertised— I am yet upon the Orations of Cicero against Verres; and the more thoroughly I know this admirable Orator, the higher my estimate of him rises— The practice which I have now adopted of allowing one hour every day to classical reading has been to me a source of so much enjoyment that I hope to persevere in it as long as life and health will permit— One year will just carry me comfortably through Cicero— The collection of the Regent’s Classics will occupy about four, if Providence has destined to me so long a date—and if my own heart and mind can derive little or no improvement from this tardy study, perhaps it may enable me to give useful hints to my Sons— I have read three or four Letters of Pliny, to compare his epistolary Style with that of Cicero— A Contrast— Every Letter of Pliny is a dissertation; intended for publication; and prepared with a Court-dress— Even the 11th. of the first book—only five lines, to express a thought repeatedly given by Cicero, is elaborate. He tells his friend, if he has nothing to write, to write that—and then comments upon this simple thought— In this Letter he says also that the practice of beginning Letters, with, Si vales, bene est, ego valeo, was no longer in use.
15. V. Saturday—

Met again Mr Hillhouse in my morning walk— Dr Phipps of Quincy called upon me. He is on his return from St. Augustine in Florida, where he has been passing the Winter—flying from a pulmonary consumption. His health is improved, but his disease is not subdued— From Charleston to this place he came on horseback; but doubts if he shall complete his journey in that manner— He has been advised not to return to Quincy before the middle of June— He saw at Savannah, Georgia Mr Cutler the Episcopal Minister at Quincy who was compelled by the same course to pass the Winter at the South—Mr Cutler left Quincy last July—Dr. Phipps in November. He supposes Mr Cutler will reach Quincy before him— He saw Lieutenant T. B. Adams at St. Augustine last Winter, and lately at Charleston— Messr Hendricks and Test of Indiana, introduced two young men, travellers from that State, and Dr Norvell announced himself as a native of Nashville Tennessee: a resident of Louisiana, and now returning thither, after having been nearly a year at Philadelphia, in attendance on the Medical Schools and Lectures there— Mr Johnson called this morning and I rode with John after dinner to the Mill— Received the Edinburgh Review N. 100. in which there are two long Articles upon Turkish Affairs— The Volume of Beloe’s Herodotus which I have taken up, and of which I have read some pages, has put me to some enquiries— There is a confusion of Chronology in my mind, concerning the Assyrian, Babylonian, Chaldean, Syrian, Median, Persian, and other antient Asiatic Monarchies— Herodotus is one of the historical fountains— The father of profane History— Born 486. years before Christ— Cotemporary with Ezra and Nehemiah and after all the scriptural prophets, except Malachi; and about one century before him. The first Book is chiefly a History of the Lydian Kingdom of which Sardis was the Capitol: and there is much about Croesus— The narrative is light, and easy, dramatized with frequent dialogue, like the Scripture Histories, and seasoned with ingenious moral reflections almost all the facts are flagrantly fabulous.
16. IV:45. Sunday— Sun rose 4:52

Heard at the Unitarian Church Mr C. H. Hedge—in the morning from Philippians 4:13. “I can do all things through Christ which the strengtheneth me.” The Sermon was ingenious, but the course of argument, savoured if not of arrogance, and rashness; at least of a sanguine temperament and youthful confidence— The text itself was taken in a more comprehensive sense than I believe the Apostle intended— The single verse indeed is without limitation—but the thought is apparently limited by the context— The passage refers to the personal support of St. Paul, which he thanks the Philippians for having taken care to provide for him— But he adds that he knows how to be abased, and how to abound—to be full and to be hungry—to abound and to suffer need— After which he offers the words of the text, saying that he can do all things— That is all things for his own personal comforts and support— But Mr Hedge understands it as a general and unqualified sense; and he vindicated the right of the apostle to say so. Urging that every individual was equally able to do all things,
he may undertake, if he have only firmness of purpose and a determined Will. A few years of experience must teach a sounder doctrine than this— I called to see judge Hay at his habitation but found he had left it last Wednesday, and was gone to his Son’s house at Georgetown— Mrs Adams with Mrs Frye, and her Son Thomas went with me to Church in the Evening— Mr Hedges text was Matthew 23.29. [“]Woe unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because ye build the tombs of the prophets and garnish the sepulchres of the righteous— 30 and say, If we had been in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets. 31. Wherefore ye be witnesses unto yourselves, that ye are the children of them, which killed the prophets”— The doctrine was the importance of self-knowledge, and the extreme frequency of self-deception— I finished reading the Orations against Verres.
17 V. Monday.

There was a Heavy Thunder Shower in the night, and several others in the course of this day. My Catarrhal cough yet continues, and I had resort this day to the medicinal remedy to which I have been accustomed in the Spring. I finished a Letter I had yesterday begun, to Benjamin Vaughan and answered one from my Son Charles— Read the Oration of Cicero for Fonteius, and an Article in the Edinburgh Review, on Providential and Prophetical Histories—For the first time I have gone through the whole of the Orations against Verres in succession. It is rather a History of Roman Tyranny in the Government of the Provinces, than an impeachment of an individual Offender— Sicily was governed by Praetors, and was required to furnish by way of tax or tribute, one tenth part of the wheat raised in the Island— Another tenth was to be furnished at fixed prices, below those of the market, and the Praetor had a discretionary power to exact a further indefinite quantity, as it might be wanted for his own establishment, and at a reasonable price— The Cities were required to furnish each an armed vessel, with a crew, and all necessary equipments, for defence against the Pirates— The people were usually priviledged to be governed by the Laws of Hiero, one of their antient kings; to which they were warmly attached, but which Verres totally disregarded— The picture of tyranny, rapacity, cruelty, debauchery, and venality, practised by Verres is stupendous— His robberies of consecrated images, relics, and exquisite works of Statuary and Sculpture, prodigious— His oppressions upon the Aratores, or wheat growing farmers, went far in three years to depopulate the Province— Cicero specifies the numbers in many of the districts, forced to abandon their farms by his exactions, and they amount to near two thirds of the whole number— By his gross mismanagement, and embezzlements, the fleet raised by the Cities for the defence against the Pirates, was run ashore and burnt by the Pirates themselves, who penetrated into the very harbour of Syracuse— Verres who in the mean time was living in drunkenness and debauchery on shore, with the wife of Cleomenes to whom he had given the command of the fleet; passes sentence of capital condemnation and puts to death the Captains of the Vessels which had been burnt— And from these wretched men, his executioner takes bribes for promises to strike off their heads at one blow; so that their torture may not be prolonged— The Orator closes the accusation with the crucifixion of Gavius the Roman Citizen, as the most aggravated of the crimes charged upon Verres; and finishes by a solemn, and magnificent prayer to each of the Gods and Goddesses, outraged by the violation of their Temples and their Images— The decorations added to the narrative of facts throughout these Orations, the descriptions of Sicilian Scenery, the mythological allusions to Ceres and Proserpine, the appeal to Publius Scipio, one of the defenders of Verres, in the name of his Ancestor
Scipio Africanus; the references of the Orator to his own situation, his exposition of the duties which he felt himself bound as a Roman Magistrate to discharge— The purity of Life which he admits he had imposed upon himself by undertaking this accusation, the enmities which he acknowledges he must encounter by its prosecution, all give occasion to luminous passages in these Orations— The style is always lofty and dignified; even when he has occasion to notice Chelidon, and Pippa, and Tertia— There is a continual effort at antithetic expressions, which sometimes appears affected; and there are rather too many puns upon the name of Verres— Throughout the whole of the six Orations the interest never flags for a moment.
18. IV:30. Tuesday.

I met Mr Hillhouse again this Morning and he walked with me round the Capitol Square. Mr Ruggles the Senator from Ohio introduced to me a Mr Shannon, his relative from Halifax, Nova-Scotia. Mr T. Munro, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening— Mrs Frye dined with us. After dinner I rode with John to the Mills, which they have been unable to work these two days, for superabundance of Water— It was worse yesterday— In the space of 15 minutes the flood in the Creek rose 6 feet—overflowed the lower floors of the Mills, and damaged 100 bushels of Meal— The water subsided as rapidly as it rose, but still runs in so heavy a sheet over the dam, that it cannot turn the wheels. It has also injured the road leading to the Mills— Those accidents engross the time and labour of the workman at the Mills, and reduce the supplies which they can furnish for the daily consumption of the City— These accidents of which there are many have a double effect upon the business, by doing damage to the works, the Stock, and the Road; and by intercepting the supply to the city markets— These Summer thunder-showers are as dangerous to Mill Establishments as to Harvests— It is not two years since one of them carried away a whole side of our dam—the repairing of which cost me nearly a year’s Rent— And the sudden flood of this time was caused by the breaking down of the dam of one of the Mills above ours upon the Creek—the timbers of which were brought down and precipitated over our dam. After finishing the Orations against Verres, I read yesterday that for Fonteius which is a short fragment, all the first part of it being lost— Fonteius had been three years Praetor in Gaul, and was prosecuted de repetundis by the Gauls as Verres had been by the Sicilians. The Gallic witnesses as against Fonteius, were so strongly pointed, that Cicero declined examining them at all, but puts the defence of his Client, upon his fair character, and witnesses favourable to him, and upon totally discrediting the Gauls— The cause was tried before Caesar’s Wars in Gaul, for one of Cicero’s topics of persuasion is that Fonteius being an experienced Military Commander should be acquitted, to be preserved for the service of the Republic, where warlike fame was much on the decline— He introduces also the widowed Mother of Fonteius, and especially his Sister who was a Vestal Virgin— And he intimates that if the judges should be inexorable to her prayers for her brother, they must expect the Gods will be equally so to her prayers for the Roman People— This is a strange idea, and indeed there is so much of address to fancy and passion in this defence as leaves room for conjecture that it was in substance very weak.
19. IV:45. Wednesday.

Mr Cadwalader is a native of Wales, and a Methodist Preacher. He is the spiritual pastor of a company of Welch Graziers settled inCounty in the State of New-York—about sixty in number; and he is soliciting subscriptions to aid them in building a Church— As they are ignorant of the English Language, Mr Cadwalader has been sent to them, to preach in their own. He says they make excellent butter which they send to the New-York Market; and some even here. He promised to send me next fall a tub of about one hundred pounds of the best to be delivered to Mr M’Kenny at Georgetown— Mr Shaler paid me a morning visit— He is now the Consul of the United States at the Havana; but like his predecessors comes to pass the Summer on the Continent— I enquired after my old friend Governor Vivés, who is he says, in good health, and in good repute— But from some of his measures he had not formed a very high opinion of his talents— I said he had the talent of a fair and candid mind; which for a Spanish Negotiator was the first, because the rarest of talents— He is the only Spanish diplomatic man, whom I have had to treat with, and who formed an exception to the character of them given by Lord Chatham— Shaler spoke of W. B. Hodgson, and asked me if I thought there would be any impropriety in his selling to the British foreign Bible Society the manuscript Translation of the book of Genesis, and three of the Gospels, which he had procured to be made in the Berber Language— I said no— But that while he remained in Office in the Department of State, he should receive nothing from any foreign individual or Society but with the knowledge and approbation of the President and Secretary of State— I rode with John to the Mill after dinner. The torrent at the dam has so far subsided that the wheel of the small Mill, and one wheel of the large one were at work, grinding Indian Corn— We found a waggon there delivering wheat. But the daily business of the Meal-Carts, is yet partially interrupted, and some hundred bushels of Indian Corn, in the warehouse at Georgetown, are getting heated—another of the dangerous accidents to be guarded against in the prosecution of this business— With Mrs Adams and Mary, I spent an hour of this evening at Mr T. B. Johnson’s— Mr and Mrs Frye, with their Son Thomas, and Mrs W. S. Smith were there— I this morning finished reading the Oration for Caecina which I had begun yesterday.— A judicial Oration addressed to recuperators—the most remarkable point in which is an argument for a liberal instead of a literal construction of words in Laws and written documents. The question was between a dejectment and an ejectment. Cicero handles the rigid construction men freely, both with raillery and with argument.
20. IV:45. Thursday.

In my walk this morning I met Mr Hillhouse who stopped, and gave me a very kind and cordial invitation if I should visit New-Haven to call and see him; which invitation he extended to my Son, and family— Why should the poor be flattered? Why should this Gentleman treat me thus now? I will give him credit for sincerity; and ascribe it to a kind and Christian temper willing to bury in oblivion all past animosities and discussions— I shall meet this disposition with a like return, and will discard the suspicions which the first manifestations of his friendly spirit excited:
I will wait for time to explain the motive of his Certificate last Spring to judge Gould— Mr Vance, member of the House of Representatives from Ohio, called with Mr Dougherty, late Marshal of the United States, but now superseded by another appointment— Vance said the successor was a respectable man; and almost the only creditable appointment made by the present Administration in the state— The Offices throughout the Union have been considered as Spoils of Victory; and they have been distributed to Sycophants and Slanderers, apparently without enquiry as to the qualification of integrity at-all—and very little as to talent. Mr Bailey introduced a Quaker friend a Postmaster at some Village in Montgomery County, Maryland; not yet dismissed from Office— I was occupied much of this Morning in assorting pamphlets to be bound up into Volumes— Rode with John this afternoon to the Mills, both of which are again at work, grinding Corn, this Evening I wrote to Dr Semple and to T. B. Adams junr— Finished reading the Oration for the Manilian Law. This is one of those that I had read in early youth— It is the first Oration of Cicero addressed to the People; and was delivered after he had been elected Praetor. He takes his Exordium from that circumstance; attributes to his modesty that he had never addressed them before; and assures them that he had been resolved never to present himself before them with crude, inexperienced or unlaboured discourse— This Oration is accordingly wrought with great skill, and polished to the highest perfection of Language— It is one continued panegyric upon Pompey—the object of it being to prevail upon the People to give the sole command of the War against Mithridates and Tigranes to Pompey— A Law to that effect having been proposed by the Tribune of the People Manilius— Catulus and Hortensius opposed the passage of the Law; and Cicero replies to their objections.— He divides the Oration into three points—the Nature of the War—its magnitude, and the choice of a Commander—and he closes by earnestly exhorting Manilius to persevere in the proposal of his Law, and by promising all the assistance in his power to carry it through; protesting with solemn adjuration of the Gods that he has no private or personal motive for giving this advice, and particularly that it is not with the view to court the favour of Pompey— The Style of eloquence is temperate, dignified, and uniform: with an occasional introduction of appropriate sentiments and reflections.
21. IV:45: Friday.

Mrs Cranch with her Son Edward called to visit the Ladies. Mr Herron and Mr Behan are Strangers from Norfolk Virginia, who called to gratify their curiosity. Mrs Isselius to make enquiries concerning the rent of the house recently occupied by Walter Jones, and from which he has removed without giving any notice— I rode after dinner with John to the Mill; the day was almost wholly absorbed in assorting pamphlets for binding— My cough hangs upon me, with appearance of being irrecoverably fixed upon my lungs— Mrs Kirke with her child, and Mrs Pitts went this day to Alexandria, and embarked in a vessel for Boston. Diarized this Evening.
The first Article in the 100th. number of the Edinburgh Review is upon Providential and prophetical Histories—by which it means Histories written, with the professed purpose, of considering the Events which they record as a series of special Providences or Miracles; and as accomplishments of scriptural prophecies— The works professedly reviewed are two, Lectures on the Philosophy of Modern History, delivered in the University of Dublin; by Dr George Miller 8 Volumes octavo—and Mahomedanism unveiled— 2. Volumes 8vo. by the Revd. Charles Forster— The manner of reviewing introduced and practiced by the Edinburgh gives one so imperfect an idea of the works professedly reviewed that I know not exactly the drift of these; but they seem to consider the Koran as a real Revelation from Heaven; and the Mahometan Imposture, as a fulfilment of the promise of God to Abraham in behalf of Ishmael— The reviewer justly considers this as very dangerous ground to tread— The Article is well and cautiously written; but in a style of reasoning from which it appears not very clear whether the Reviewer is a Christian or a Freethinker— He has some marks of an Infidel in disguise— The next Article couples a Speech of M. T. Sadler M.P. at Whitby, with a History of political Economy in Italy by Pecchio— Sadler is a young Irish Member of Parliament, and a great champion of the old English System of restricted trade, against the liberal political economists—that is the political cheats, for in England they are nothing else. I pass by Lieutt Maw’s descent of the Amazon; and come to Inghirami’s Etruscan Monuments 6. Vol’s 4to. and Müller prize Essay upon the Etruscan’s 2 Vol’s 8vo. all upon Etruscan History and Antiquities— They suppose the Etruscans to have been a mixture of aboriginals, with Lydian Tyrrhinians from Asia Minor.
22. IV:45. Saturday.

Finished the Assortment of my pamphlets for binding: from Vol. 15 to 36. Alecto 3. Bundle 3. American Minstrelsy 1. Adams and Jefferson. 1. Salon de Gand 1. Recueil de Brochures 1. and several parcels of refuse left— Mary dined at Mr Frye’s. I rode with John after dinner to the Mills—two wheels again grinding corn— The week not so brisk as several that preceded. After returning home, I called and spent an hour of the Evening with Mr Rush— Mrs Rush and part of the family were gone to the theatre— Three of their children have had the measles— Two others have them now— This has delayed the removal of the family from the City— He has determined to remove to York, and expects to go in the course of the next Month— He told me some particulars of the late Jefferson birth day dinner lately got up by Benton and Calhoun to proclaim anti-tariff and nullification doctrine under the shelter of Jefferson’s name. The ostensible purpose was to honour Jefferson’s birth-day; by an assemblage of Members of Congress, dining together upon Republican principles— The real object was to trick the Pennsylvania Members into the drinking of anti-tariff and nullification toasts. Eight members of the Pennsylvania delegation; Jefferson Republican dyed in the Wool, agreed to go— The company were assembled— The President was there by invitation— George R. Leiper one of the Pennsylvania members, told Miller, his colleague one of the toast-making Committee, that he should like to see the toasts before drinking them. Miller brought him the list of toasts, and read them till he came to the 13th. when Leiper told him he had enough—he need not read any more— He then collected the whole eight
together and told them he should not sit down at the table where these toasts were to be drank; and they all agreed to withdraw together, which they accordingly did.— The obnoxious toasts were drank— But President Jackson being called upon for his toast, gave “The Union—it must be preserved.”— Aio te, AEacida, Romanos vincere posse— And from that day the two sides of the faction have been each claiming the Presidential toast to itself. The Union must be preserved says South-Carolina, by repealing the Tariff— The Union must be preserved says Pennsylvania, by sustaining the Tariff to the muzzle of the gun— Since the dinner Leiper has published a Letter from Mr Jefferson to his father, charging opposition to domestic manufactures upon the anglo-federalists. In conversing with Mr Rush upon the prospects of the Country, we agreed that the Indians are already sacrificed— That the Public Lands will be given away— That domestic Industry and internal Improvement will be strangled—and when the public debt will be paid off and the Bank Charter expired, there will be no great interest left upon which the action of the general Government will operate— The future must be consigned to the sweet little Cherub that sits up aloft.
23. V. Sunday.

A cold, rainy, cheerless day needing a fire little less than January; but I had none. Morning Service at the Presbyterian Church— Heard Mr Campbell from 1. Corinthians 2.4. “And my speech, and my preaching was not with enticing words of man’s wisdom, but in demonstration of the Spirit and of power.”— The argument of Mr Campbell was that the success of the gospel was not at all promoted by the arts of human eloquence but entirely by the special operation of the holy Spirit— Such is the course of reasoning in the Chapter from which this text is borrowed; but St. Paul did not always disdain the aids of human eloquence. He availed himself of them with great power in preaching at Athens— Nor does it follow because the Apostles did possess and exercise supernatural power in the performance of their duties, that the same assistance can be expected by the preachers of the Gospel at this Time— They must use to the utmost of the power the enticing words of man’s wisdom, and the more thoroughly they are qualified by learning and study, and the more fervently they apply themselves to the acquisition and to the use of human eloquence the more effectually will they serve the Cause of their Lord and Master, and the more cause will they have to hope for that aid of the holy Spirit, which may shed a blessing upon their labours— Yesterday Morning I finished the reading of the Apocryphal Books and this Morning began upon the New-Testament— The Historical Books of the Apocrypha, are very unworthy to be bound in a Volume with the Scriptures of the Old and New Testament— There is a link of connection wanting between the Books of Ezra, and Nehemiah and the Maccabees on one side; and between the Maccabees and the Gospel Histories on the other— The Maccabees, appear suddenly as Military Commanders and High Priests, waging Wars with the kings of Syria, and Egypt, it scarcely appears
how or why— There is a peculiar Chronology used in the Books of the Maccabees, the AEra of which I have not ascertained. The two Books are accounts by different authors in part of the same transactions— The second Book ending with the Death of Nicanor, which is told Chapter 7. verse 43 of the first— The second Book is avowedly a mere abridgment of a work in five Books by Jason of Cyrene and the Abridger considers his work, as more difficult and laborious than that of the original author— At the close of the 12th. Chapter there is a story of a contribution for offering up prayers for the dead, which is expressly approved, and is considered by Roman Catholic as establishing the doctrine of purgatory. And there is a horrible story of seven brothers and their Mother suffering death for refusing to eat Swine’s flesh— The Style is remarkable for its inanity. There was no Evening service at Mr Baker’s—and the Rain confined me at home—
24. IV:45. Monday.

Mr John Cranch came and requested of me a Letter of introduction to Mr Leslie in London, which I promised— He said he proposed in the course of the Summer to embark for Leghorn, and to spend if possible two years in Italy, after which he intends to go to England— His object is to improve himself in the art of painting, for which he has a strong natural talent— Mr Deeble took my collection of pamphlets to bind them— Mr Johnson was here before dinner— Mr Rush called to take leave and I returned the collection of my father’s Letters to him, which he lent me about two years since, and of which he has repeatedly requested the return— Mr Handy and Mr Gilliss came together. I had sent to ask to see Mr Handy before my departure for the North— Mr Handy shewed me a passage from a Letter of Mr Barker to him, making acknowledgment for my allowance of six Months longer for him to try the chance of obtaining more for his house than I offered—a price which he thinks rather too low. I shall wait therefore till the Autumn— I agreed also to leave the Note from the Treasurer of the Presbyterian Church as it now stands—but disagreed to one charge for fifty Months of a contribution which was undertaken to pay the Note to me, and to which I did aid, until after all the others had ceased— And as the Note was not paid; I did not think the charge should remain on me alone, merely to reduce the debt to me. The accrueing interest upon the Note now rather more than pays the charge upon my pew. Mrs Tudor sent this afternoon, requesting me to call and see her— I went immediately and her object was to talk of her deceased son William— Mrs Stewart who had recovered from the first shock of their loss, read me Extracts from several of her brothers Letters, very creditable to his character. I told them that I had offered Alexander H. Everett to write a biographical notice of William Tudor for the North-American Review and that he had accepted the Offer. Mrs Tudor requested me to return the Memorandum which she sent me— I finished reading Cicero’s Oration for Cluentius which presents a Scene of complicated human depravity; such as one would hope to be without example in modern times— Undoubted corruption by bribery of the judges—but whether the bribery was by Cluentius or by the father of the Prosecutor—Oppianicus— He was dead, and one of the charges against Cluentius was that he had caused him to be murdered by poison— But Cicero charges him with six or eight atrocious murders; and among them two of his own children— This is the Oration of which the Analysis is given in Blair’s Lectures. It has otherwise I believe not been translated into the English Language.
25. IV.45 Tuesday.

Mr Fendall was here this morning, and I gave him the manuscript of my observations upon Parties, which he wishes to use for the composition of his Preliminary Chapter to the History of the last Administration upon which he said it was his intention to commence immediately. Mr and Mrs Frye dined with us— I received a Letter from my Son Charles, which produced a change in our arrangements for the Journey to Quincy. Charles had written to me; proposing to pass the Summer with us at Quincy; intimating that his wife wished to pass the Summer at Medford with her father. I answered him inviting him and his wife to reside with us; his wife to visit her father as might be agreeable to herself. I had also invited John’s wife to go with us, and to take her child, to which she had agreed— Charles’s Letter this day received informs me that he has concluded not to leave his house, for several reasons, and among other because we shall not be alone— Thereupon John’s wife declines going with us, and the child is not to be separated from its Mother—we are therefore to go without them—
26. IV:45. Wednesday.

Mr Mulkey is a Welsh Methodist Clergyman, Minister of a Church in the Western part of New-York, composed of settlers, natives of Wales and speaking only the Welsh Language— He came for a contribution to complete the building of the Church. He said they made very excellent butter, and I bespoke a firkin of about 100 pounds to be delivered the next Autumn Dr Huntt was here and I consulted him upon the state of my health, which is bad. The Catarrhal cough which has afflicted me the whole Winter still hangs upon me. Dr Huntt recommends warm salted baths. Mr Fendall came, and I gave him my manuscript upon parties, yet unfinished, and which he is to return. I put together all the books that he had lent me, and left direction with my Son John to send them back to him— I sent back also the books I had borrowed from the Department of State— Sidney Brooks paid us a morning visit. He is here upon an excursion from New-York, with his wife and her Sister for health. Ward and Matthews were strangers; visitors from curiosity. Mr Johnson, and Mrs Smith came to bid us farewell. Mrs Smith had written me a Letter, stating that her husband’s was declining, and that she thought a Summer visit to the Bedford Springs might restore him—and enquiring if I could assist him to incur the necessary expence. I told her there might be a sum of about 100 dollars coming to him from my father’s bequest; to be paid perhaps in the course of a year, and that if Mr Smith should want the money and obtain permission to go to Bedford, I would pay him to that amount in advance— The Senators Bell, Burnet and Naudain, called on me this afternoon— I visited Mrs Tudor, and afterwards called again at the request of Mrs Stewart— Mentioned to them the proposal I had made to A. H. Everett, to write a biographical account of William Tudor, to be inserted in the North-American Review, and Mr Everett’s answer, that he would apply to Frederick Tudor, for the particulars relating to the early part of his brother’s life, which would be needful for the narrative. Mrs Tudor thought Frederick could not give them; and Mrs Stewart was unwilling that there
should be any reference to Frederick— They spoke of him with the kind feeling of family affection, but as of a character totally uncongenial with that of his brother.— My Son John received this day a Letter from Charles, upon which he and his wife concluded, that she and her child should go with us to Quincy as had been determined before the flurry of yesterday— I have continued reading the Orations of Cicero, and this morning finished the three against the Agrarian Law proposed by the Tribune, P. Servilius Rullus— The first of the three was delivered in the Senate, on the day upon which Cicero entered on the Consular Office— All the first part of it is lost.— The second and third of the Orations were to the People, and defeated a fraudulent project of speculation in the Sales of public Lands, a cheat which Rullus would have passed upon the People, as for their benefit.
27. IV:45. Thursday—

Baltimore— We commenced our Journey this morning in two divisions— My wife, with my Son John’s wife; his infant daughter, and Mrs Nowland, left Washington at 8 O’Clock in our own Carriage and a pair of horses driven by John Kirke— Half an hour later I started in the Stage, of Fuller’s line, with a black Servant named WilliamIn the Stage with me was Mr Butman, a member of the House of Representatives from Maine— Mr Henderson, once the husband of Coll. John Laurens’s daughter— Ex-Lieutenant Webb, a personage of transient notoriety, and a family from Philadelphia— At the door of a house where we took in a passenger, Mr Thomas Chilton, a member of the house from Kentucky, of versatile fame and opinions was introduced to me— We passed our Carriage standing at the door at Rossburg Tavern, and at 3. in the afternoon we landed at Barnum’s Hotel—Baltimore— While we were dining we received an invitation, from the Committee of the Railway Company to take a ride, out to Ellicott’s Mills— Mr Butman declined; feeling himself under a necessity to proceed in the Night line of Stage and steam-boat, which left Baltimore at 5 P.M. and still goes by the way of Frenchtown and Newcastle— Mr Henderson and myself accepted the invitation, and went accompanied by Mr William Patterson, and Mr Wever the Superintendent of the Road— At four P.M. we set out— Six Cars of different forms, each drawn by a single horse. The Car in which I rode had the form of a double Stage Coach; with a door at one side, and a bench round the inside upon which fourteen persons were seated— Eight others were on the out side—six on the top; and one each side of the driver— The horse was changed twice on the road, and we travelled the 13. Miles to the Mills in an hour and a half— After resting about 10 minutes, we returned, in the same time it had taken us to go out. I rode out by the side of the driver, and returned within the Car, with ten Lady Passengers— The embankments, the deep Cuts, the Carroll and Patterson Viaducts or Bridges, constitute altogether a work of great enterprize, labour and expense. Mr Patterson speaks with great confidence of the continuance of the work; but it cannot pay its cost, and unless the Government comes to their assistance by a large subscription, the Capital in the City of Baltimore must sink under the pressure of the undertaking before it will be half completed. They are severely disappointed by the failure of their application to Congress for a subscription at the present Session. On returning to Barnum’s Hotel; about Sunset I found my family had been about half an hour arrived— Mr John Sergeant of Philadelphia, was there, and spent the Evening with us— He is going to Fayetteville in North-Carolina. We had a succession of Visitors the whole Evening; among whom was Mr W. Barney the late Naval Officer, and Mrs Barney; lately much celebrated for a spirited Letter to the President of the United States, on the dismission of her husband from Office.
28. IV:30. Friday— From Baltimore to Philadelphia.

There are two lines of Steam-boats and Stages between Baltimore and Philadelphia, which now run in competition with each other— The Old Union Line, who have two new Steam-Boats; the George Washington from Baltimore to the Canal at Black Creek, and the Robert Morris, from Delaware City to Philadelphia on the Delaware— The other is called the Citizen’s Line—and their Steam-boats are the Charles Carroll of Carrollton from Baltimore to the Canal; and the William Penn, from Philadelphia to the Canal at Delaware City. John Kirke had first applied at the boat of the Citizens Line— But by the advice of Sergeant and W. Barney, we concluded to take the old Union line, and came in the Washington Captain Robinson from Baltimore. The boats of both lines leave the wharves at six in the morning, at half past ten we were in black Creek at the entrance of the Canal— Here the passengers and their baggage, passed and were transferred into the Canal barge; one of which is connected with each of the lines. I was obliged to leave my Carriage and horses, at the entrance of the Canal— The barges not being of size to receive and transport them— I directed John Kirke to take them by the road over which I travelled last Summer; and to join us if possible at the City of Delaware landing. And if he should find this impracticable; as Captain Robinson thought he would, I ordered him to go up to Newcastle, and take the horses and Carriage thence to Philadelphia in the Night boat of the Union line— The Canal barges travel at the rate of six miles an hour— They are towed by four and sometimes by five horses, in file, with a rider on the foremost, and a rider on the hindmost horse—changing horses once on the way— They pass under the deep cut bridge and descend in eight minutes the lock, four miles from the City of Delaware— The tow-path is often barely wide enough, for the horses travelling in opposition, to pass by each other. The canal is forty feet wide, and the embankments, look as if a severe Storm would make breaches in any part of them. At one O’Clock we passed in 8 minutes from the Canal Barge into the Steam-boat Robert Morris at the Delaware City, Captain Jenkins. John Kirke had not arrived— After touching at Newcastle to land and take in passengers, we landed at Chesnut Street wharf at Philadelphia in ten hours from Baltimore. This is now daily performed by two lines of boats— We had as fellow passengers from Baltimore Mr Cooper of Norfolk, Captain and Mrs Newell, and many others— We came to lodge at Head’s Mansion House— Just before reaching the Black Creek Canal Landing, we discovered that one of our Trunks had been left behind; but whether at home or at Barnum’s in Baltimore we did not know. I wrote to Barnum and to my Son John to enquire after it. In the Evening D. Hoffman of Baltimore, and C. C. Biddle with his Son called upon me—and William C. Greenleaf whom my Son John has engaged to assist him in the business of the Mill— He came from Boston yesterday Morning; and proceeds for Washington to-morrow—
29— V.45. Saturday.

William C. Greenleaf went at 7 this morning— I gave him a Letter for my Son John— We waited the whole day expecting the arrival of John Kirke with the Horses and Carriage, but he did not come— Finding that we shall be detained here till Monday Morning, I wrote to my Son Charles at Boston, not to expect us at Quincy before next Wednesday and perhaps not till a day or two later. It was a day of tedious waiting and suspense, not much alleviated by a succession of visitors, this whole day long— Judge Baldwin of the Supreme Court of the

United States, and judge Hopkinson of the district Court, were among them— They are now holding the Circuit Court; two days since they passed sentence of death upon two mail-robbers. Mr Brown late Minister of the United States in France, has lodgings with Mrs Brown at Head’s— He called upon me, and I returned his visit. He told me that Richard Raynal Keene had commenced a suit against him in a Court at New-Orleans, laying his damages at thirty thousand dollars, for his refusal to furnish him a Passport while Mr Brown was Minister in France— Mr Brown assigned very sufficient reasons for refusing the Passport; and asked me if there was any Law requiring that any Minister of the United States abroad should grant Passports— There is none— It is a mere practice founded on usage—and the Passports are all gratuitously given— Mr Connell mentioned to me that a Messenger had gone on to Washington, with a Treaty negotiated by Mr Wheaton in Denmark, securing 650000 dollars of indemnity to the claimants of indemnity for spoliations upon commercial property in 1809. and 10. Connell told me that he had recently lost a Child— I dined at Mr Charles J. Ingersoll’s with his three Sons, Mr Duponceau, R. Walsh junr. J. Vaughan, and David Paul Brown, who was introduced to me as an eminent practitioner at the Bar; and much distinguished in Literature— Some discussion arose at table, upon the cause of the decline of the Public relish for theatrical performances— I somewhat indiscreetly enquired if it was not owing to the barrenness of the age; and the total vacuity of dramatic master-pieces—when I was informed that Mr D. P. Brown himself had recently published a Tragedy, called Sertorius— Mr Brown took no offence however at my remark, and afterwards sent me a copy of his Tragedy, which I read— It requires high talent to compose an indifferent Drama and perhaps I ought to distrust my own judgment upon that species of composition. At least I have thought so since hearing of the failure of De Montfort, and the success of Fazio upon the Stage. My Evening visitors were Mr West one of the Sons of the famed Painter, and William Short once the favourite of Mr Jefferson— West has degenerated into an Englishman double-distilled— He has come to this Country for the sole purpose of fleecing the people by contributions for looking at his father’s picture of Christ rejected— He came here in April and he told me that twenty-four thousand persons had already visited his exhibition room; upon each of whom he has levied a quarter of a dollar. Mr Short is enjoying in solitary old age, the fortune which he made while in the public service.
30. V.30. Sunday.
