Waited all this day, with anxiety still growing more intense for the arrival of John Kirke, with the Horses and Carriage—disappointment and suspense— Mr Vaughan called, and accompanied me to the Unitarian Church— As I was going out I met judge Ambrose Spencer now a member of the House of Representatives, just arrived from Washington which he left yesterday Morning. The President, on Friday returned the Bill authorising a subscription to the Maysville and Lexington road, with his reasons for refusing to sign it. The Message is of ambiguous purport blending together objections Constitutional and of expediency. It produced an angry debate, and the
vote in the house upon the Bill, after reading the objections was 96 for and 90 against the Bill— The system of internal improvements is thus arrested by the fiat of the President against a decided majority of both houses of Congress— It is a critical trial of the Constitution and of the Union— Mr Furness at the Unitarian Church preached from John 18.38. “What is Truth.”— He said nothing in the discourse of the occasion upon which these words were spoken; nor did he give a very satisfactory answer to Pilate’s question— Has it ever been answered? Truth has reference to the words and thoughts of Man. It is not the mere existence of things nor is it yet the idea of the human mind concerning them— Truth is the conformity between the words, and thoughts, and realities in the communication of ideas from man to man. In the Greek Testament the word is alηθεια, unconcealment— It belongs to the properties of the mind rather than to the nature of things— Jesus told Pilate that he came into the world to bear witness of the Truth; and that every one who was of the Truth heard his voice— That truth was that he was the king of the Jews, but that his kingdom was not of this world— But the assertion of the kingdom itself is not direct, but informed from the question of Pilate— I dined with Judge Hopkinson. Mary had also been invited, but was not well and sent an excuse— Miss Mease, and Richard Peters were there besides the family— Peters went away after dark, and Dr Chapman soon afterwards came in— There were heavy showers of Rain, and we sat at the table talking till eleven at Night— I supposed it about nine, till as I was returning to my lodgings two watchmen, by whom I passed gave me notice of the real hour. A principal cause of my remaining so late and talking so incessantly was the anxiety grating all the time upon my mind.
31. V: Monday— From Philadelphia to New-Brunswick.

I passed a sleepless Night, in unremitted Agitation, at hearing nothing from John Kirke, the horses and Carriage. Soon after rising this morning I went to the Chesnut Street wharf, on board the Robert Morris, and enquired of Captain Jenkins if he could give me any information of my Coachman, Carriage and Horses— He told me that they had come up in the boat from Newcastle on Friday Night—and that Kirke, supposing that we had gone on to New-York, proceeded immediately in the boat to Trenton, without stopping at all at Philadelphia— I was thus relieved from deep anxiety, and our course was plain before us— After breakfast I called at the United States Bank, and saw Mr Biddle the President. He had passed part of Saturday Evening with us— I had received on Saturday from Mr George Rundle Treasurer of the Schuylkill permanent bridge, dividends on my stock since Octr. 1824. by a check on one of the banks of Philadelphia, for which Mr Biddle gave me in exchange one upon the U.S. Branch Bank in Boston— I also called on Baron Krudener—the Russian Minister at his lodgings, and found Captain Newell with him— He is waiting for the Chargé d’Affaires Lomonossof, and is then to embark for Europe, on leave of absence— I did not expect ever to see him again, and parted from him, with good wishes that he might have a pleasant voyage and prosperous after-times.
At noon we took the Burlington Steam-boat— We found Mr John Vaughan at the wharf to see us off— While waiting for the boat in a shop at the corner of the street I saw Baron Krudener pass by— But Mr Wallenstein joined us, and told me that the Baron had been very desirous of having a conversation with me, and much mortified that he had company with him when I called at his lodgings— That he wished much to see me again, and would for that purpose meet me either at New-York or at Boston— I desired Mr Wallenstein to assure the Baron that I should be happy to meet him at Boston at any time during the Summer; but that I should make no stay at New-York. The Steam boat landed us at Bordentown between three and four O’Clock—on board the boat was a family of Quakers among whom John Hunt of Darby and his wife, who gave me a very cordial invitation to his house, if I should ever pass that way— And Anthony Taylor, whom I had met in the boat last December; and who also invited me to his house near Bristol— We rode in the Stage form Bordentown to Trenton, 7. miles; and made enquiries there at several public houses for John Kirke, our horses and Carriage, but could hear nothing of them. He had not even been seen at any of the Stage or Steam-boat Houses— I was uncertain whether he had gone on to New-York, or remained waiting for us at some other public house in Trenton— We had lost the chance of proceeding in the Stage; but I took a separate Carriage with a pair of Horses, and came on, after calling at Mr. Southard’s house, and requesting him to ascertain whether our Coachman was in Trenton; and if he was to direct him to come on to us at New-York— Mr Southard warmly invited us to alight at his house, but we could not stay— We saw his brother Coll. Southard with him at his door. We came on through Princeton to Follett’s at New-Brunswick, where we arrived at half-past nine in the Evening— Kirke had been there Saturday Night, and went on Sunday Morning to New-York— I met this morning on the wharf at Philadelphia, Mr H. R. Storrs, member from the interior of New-York of the House of Representatives; who came from Washington yesterday Morning. Both Houses of Congress sat all Saturday Night—and sent the President four internal improvement Bills, as Comments upon his Maysville Message.

Day. The first three weeks of the Month like the preceding from the beginning of the year. Since then preparations for Travel and Travel— With a family so infirm—that every step I take is with fear and trembling. I cannot express what I feel— If I had concern only for my own life, my condition would be comparatively happy— I have no reliance upon Earth— May that from above be sure and stedfast.
